title.narrative: DRA Ukraine Joint Response phase 4

description.narrative: SO1: Advocate for and respond to protection needs SO2: Provide emergency assistance SO3: Improve resilience and prevent further degradation

The Joint Response program will focus on the most vulnerable people in Eastern Ukraine. Groups that are specifically targeted are IDPs, children, youth, foster families, female-headed households, elderly, persons with a disability, trauma or chronic disease, people without access to social benefits and food insecure people of working age without any income. A cumulative vulnerability scoring tool will be used to prioritise between and within groups. The tool and methodology builds on the experiences of UkJR2 and UkJR3. The scoring will be made context-appropriate through focus group discussions. Vulnerability criteria will be harmonised with UN recommendations to ensure a country-wide coordinated targeting for particular activities.

To provide emergency assistance and protection to 34.435 of the most vulnerable people affected by the humanitarian crisis in Eastern Ukraine. The fourth phase of the Ukraine Joint Response will intervene in the priority sectors Food Security and Livelihoods, Protection and Shelter/NFI. The cross-sectoral modality of Multi-Purpose Cash (MPC) will be used. Activities in the Joint Response plan are aligned with Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) activities. Through the program outlined below the Joint Response will make an essential contribution to reach the strategic objectives for Ukraine in 2018.

activity-date.narrative: Due to the Phase Out of Dutch Relief Alliance Joint Response, the planned end date shifted to 30-6-2019

title.narrative: Programme with vulnerable families, families with newborns, pregnant women and children

description.narrative: Consultations with parents on PSS and NFI activities.

title.narrative: PHASE OUT - Number of people provided with non-food items

description.narrative: In the phasing out period, provision of NFI needs is focused on response to individual needs of the most vulnerable UKJR4 families with children. Activities include provision of newborn kits for families in Luhansk, and provision of NFI to cover individual needs such as winterization, improvement of housing, buying clothes, school supplies, and diapers for children 0-3 years old. This activity contributes to a sustainable phase out by supporting the most vulnerable families during the cold period in January-March. During April-June there are two scenarios of phasing out. In case JR partners find funds for continuation of the program, these families will continue to receive NFI as a part of on-going comprehensive family support. In case there are no such funding, there are three months left for phasing out of all families in accordance to individual family plans. Such plans are based on family needs assessment, evaluation of self-sustainability and risks for children to be deprived of parental care. Options include: leaving the program, referrals to other projects by JR partners, referral to other NGOs and public services.

PHASE OUT - Number of children that received support specified to their needs

description.narrative: Specialized protection services for vulnerable families based on case management (Stanytsa Luhansk and Luhansk). Psychosocial support (PSS) for individuals & group consultations, psychological therapy for children, pss via creative and recreational activities for children, support of cognitive development of children.
